Kentucky has the fifth highest overdose mortality rate in the nation, and it is essential that we continue to secure these resources for the Commonwealth to combat this tragic crisis.

I have been a strong and consistent advocate for the University of Kentucky’s initiatives to combat the opioid crisis, and I was particularly proud to support their application for the HEALing Communities Study. 

 https://barr.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/congressman-barr-applauds-hhs-for-awarding-healing-communities-study …

An apology would be a step toward restoring a culture of respect among Members of the U.S. House of Representatives.

The comments made by Rep. Ocasio-Cortez demonstrate a lack of civility that is becoming far too common in the U.S. House of Representatives. Regardless of political party, beliefs or ideology, we need to treat all of our colleagues with respect and dignity.

Today, I delivered the letter below to @AOC, calling on her to apologize for  her comments to our colleague  @DanCrenshawTX before she plans her trip to Kentucky to learn how the Green New Deal could impact our Commonwealth. pic.twitter.com/j52dAcIi4E

It is important that we create policies that discourage early plant retirements, support innovation, and ensure the long term reliability of our energy grid. Thank you to Kentucky State Rep. @MelindaPrunty for being part of this important discussion.

This morning I joined fellow members of Congressional Coal Caucus, including Rep. James Comer and our chairman, Rep. David McKinley of West Virginia, to discuss the retirement of the TVA-Paradise 3 power plant and the economic effects of its closure on the community. pic.twitter.com/knnMqiEYPO
